title: 104_hr2414
content: The "Youth Smoking Prevention Act of 1995" prohibits the Secretary of Health and Human Services from regulating tobacco and nicotine products under certain acts. Federal authority to regulate these products is tied to states receiving the Federal preventive health and health services block grant. SEC. 3. REGULATION OF STATE AUTHORITY. The Public Health Service Act is amended to prohibit the sale of tobacco and nicotine products to individuals under 18 years old, requiring age verification through a photo ID. The Public Health Service Act prohibits the sale of tobacco and nicotine products to individuals under 18 years old. Violators will be fined or required to perform community service or attend education on smoking hazards. The Public Health Service Act prohibits the sale of tobacco and nicotine products to individuals under 18 years old. Violators will be fined or required to perform community service or attend education on smoking hazards. Violators presenting false identification for tobacco purchase will face fines, community service, and education. It is unlawful to sell individual cigarettes or packages with less than 20 cigarettes. Violators will be fined similar to selling alcohol to minors. Vending machines for cigarettes must be in plain view. Vending machines for cigarettes must be in plain view and under direct supervision, except in specific locations like private clubs, bars, or areas with minimal underage workers. It is unlawful to make tobacco products available to individuals under 18 in self-service displays not supervised by someone over 18. Violators will be fined. It is unlawful to distribute free samples of tobacco and other nicotine-containing products to individuals under 18 through the mail or otherwise. Distributing tobacco products through the mail to individuals under 18 is also prohibited. Violators will be fined in the same amount as those who sell alcohol to minors under State law. The distribution of tobacco and nicotine products through the mail is prohibited and will be penalized according to Title 39, United States Code. Retail sales of these products must be supervised, with signs displaying purchase age, health warnings, and penalties for violations. Violators will face fines similar to those selling alcohol to minors. The fine for selling alcoholic beverages to a minor under State law is specified. Retail establishments selling tobacco products must inform employees about the prohibition of sales to individuals under 18. Employees must sign a form acknowledging this notice within 30 days of the enactment of the law. Employees must sign a form acknowledging prohibited acts related to selling cigarettes. Owners must retain these forms for inspections. Failure to do so results in a fine of $100 to $250. A license is required for retail sale of cigarettes, issued by the State with specified conditions and penalties for violations. The State is responsible for conducting annual random inspections of tobacco outlets to prevent sales to individuals under 18. Billboards advertising tobacco products containing nicotine are prohibited. The brand names and logos of tobacco products containing nicotine cannot be marketed to minors, including toys and video games. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act have updated the years for certain provisions. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act update years for certain provisions related to noncompliance and enforcement percentages. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act update years for certain provisions related to noncompliance and enforcement percentages. U.S.C. sec. 300x-26 is amended to allow states to use grant funds to enforce laws described in subsection (a). The Secretary of Health and Human Services must provide an annual report to Congress on states' compliance with the amended section of the Public Health Service Act.
